g:HTMLPanel.p: Although the UIBinder chapter uses the S-Mart Login Form as the example widget throughout the chapter, there were several versions of this widget as well as several other examples that had nothing to do with the widget. To help you better understand the material we have created this demo, which includes in addition to the final LoginFormBox each version of the login form as well as the other examples.
We hope that you learn as much from this Demo application as you do from each of the examples.

Show/Hide S-Mart Login - This will display or hide the finished S-Mart login form as it was designed to be displayed, which is approximately the center of the page and overlaying any existing content.

Show/Hide S-Mart Alt Login - This will display or hide an alternately styled version of the login form. This was the original design but it had to be changed because it was too dark for use in the book. So we included it as an example of how to use the @UiTemplate annotation to provide two layouts for the same widget.
S-Mark Login (v1) - This will display version 1 of the login form, which has no styling and no event handling.

S-Mark Login (v2) - This will display version 2 of the login form, which included the additional error message HTML code in the template. Although the template fields are bound to the Java class, there is still no styling or event handling.
DisclosurePanel Example - An example of using the DisclosurePanel in the template with the header tag.
SplitLayoutPanel Example - An example of using the SplitLayoutPanel in the template with directional tags.
Radio Buttons Example - An example of using RadioButton in a template. RadioButton uses @UiConstructor to read the name attribute into the RadioButton constructor.
ClientBundle Example - An example of using @UiFactory to create use a static instance of a ClientBundle and to ensure that a CssResource is properly initialized.
